matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same vulnerability - SQL injection in the category filter/parameter on the homepage. The actual findings provide detailed POC evidence of error-based, boolean-based, and UNION-based SQL injection attacks on the category parameter, which directly corresponds to the expected finding of SQL injection in the category filter at line 46 of index.php.

missed.title: SQL Injection in Admin Login
missed.reason: The expected finding describes SQL injection in admin.php at line 21 for the admin login authentication. While the actual findings include a 'Type Juggling Vulnerability in Admin Authentication' and multiple CSRF/authentication-related findings, there is no explicit SQL injection finding for the admin login endpoint. The actual findings focus on type juggling and authentication bypass via array parameters, but do not document direct SQL injection in the admin login query itself.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate security vulnerability not in the expected findings list. The admin login form lacks CSRF token protection, allowing cross-site request forgery attacks. This is a valid and important finding that should be addressed.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Admin Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery (duplicate report) - Same vulnerability as above but documented as a separate finding. Both reports confirm the lack of CSRF tokens and SameSite cookie protection on the admin login form.

extra.title: Insecure Session Cookie Security Flags
extra.assessment: New discovery - The session cookie lacks HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags. This is a critical security misconfiguration that allows JavaScript access to session tokens and makes the application vulnerable to XSS-based session hijacking and CSRF attacks.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Seven critical security headers are missing: Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Strict-Transport-Security, Referrer-Policy, and X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies. This weakens overall application security posture.

extra.title: No Rate Limiting on Authentication Attempts
extra.assessment: New discovery - The admin login endpoint accepts unlimited authentication attempts without rate limiting, account lockout, or exponential backoff. This enables brute force attacks on admin credentials.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - PHP Error Messages and Version Leakage
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application displays detailed PHP error messages revealing file paths and line numbers, and exposes the PHP version (7.4.33) via the X-Powered-By header. This aids attacker reconnaissance.

extra.title: Type Juggling Vulnerability in Admin Authentication - Array Parameter Injection
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application accepts array parameters in POST requests which are passed to mysqli_real_escape_string(), causing PHP warnings and type juggling. This indicates insufficient input validation on the authentication endpoint and could potentially be exploited for authentication bypass.

extra.title: Information Disclosure through PHP Notices and Error Messages in Admin Panel
extra.assessment: New discovery - PHP notices and warnings display sensitive information about code structure, file paths, and line numbers when array parameters are submitted to the admin endpoint. This is a secondary information disclosure vulnerability related to the type juggling issue.

extra.title: Weak or Missing Password Policy on Admin Login
extra.assessment: New discovery - The admin login form does not enforce any password policy requirements. The application accepts extremely weak passwords (1 character, single letters) without validation. This significantly increases the risk of brute force attacks succeeding, especially when combined with the lack of rate limiting.

extra.title: Stored XSS via SQL Injection - Unsafe Output Rendering
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application is vulnerable to Stored XSS through a chain of SQL injection plus unsafe output rendering. An attacker can use UNION-based SQL injection to inject malicious HTML/JavaScript that is rendered without proper escaping, allowing arbitrary code execution in user browsers.
